;越来越多的韩国人购买日本货币并作为日元前往日本汇率贬值至八年来的最低水平。

;

;汇率接近每 100 日元兑 900 韩元（0.71 美元），周二跌至每 100 日元兑 904 韩元，这是自以来的最低水平2015 年 6 月。

;

;考虑到 4 月份汇率处于 1,000 韩元的水平，市场观察家对如此急剧的下跌感到惊讶。他们谨慎地预测，该汇率可能很快就会跌破 900 韩元。

;

;日元走弱的主要原因是日本和其他主要经济体的不同货币政策。日本一直保持货币宽松政策，而许多其他国家则效仿美联储收紧货币政策。

;

;日本“挤满”游客，而中国游客甚至还没有回来

;

;最近外国投资涌入韩国金融市场导致韩元相对升值，也加速了这一趋势。

;

;这导致越来越多的韩国人开始购买日本的

;

;截至周三，韩国主要商业银行的日元存款余额为 8082 亿日元，比 5 月底增长 15.8%。在短短 10 个工作日内，韩国人的账户增加了 1103 亿日元。

;

;本月早些时候购买了大量日元的上班族 Kim Ju-yeon 说，她认为没有理由不这样做

;

;“此时购买日元非常有吸引力。韩元兑日元的平均汇率约为每 100 日元兑换 1,000 韩元。一旦恢复到正常水平，我预计投资回报率将在 10% 左右，这是我预期的最低水平，”Kim 说。

;

;尽管今年第二季度总体而言考虑到淡季，前往日本旅游的韩国人数量明显激增。甚至有人说去日本旅行比在东南亚旅行更划算。

;

;根据航空统计，6月1日至10日期间，有89,847人乘坐仁川和东京之间的航线。这是与 1 月份前 10 天的 66,741 人次相比增加了 34.6。

;

;飞往日本的低成本航空公司平均预订率为 90%，促使航空业增加航班数量并为日本引入新的目的地。

;

;但是，有人担心日元长期贬值会削弱韩国的出口竞争力。

;

;日本削减私人飞机和超级游艇的繁文缛节以吸引超级富有的游客

;

;日元比韩元走弱使得日本产品在海外市场上比韩国产品更便宜。由于许多游客选择日本而不是韩国，国内服务业也可能受到负面影响。

;

;不过，日元疲软预计将暂时持续。日本央行可能维持鸽派政策，导致日元进一步贬值。预计今年下半年韩元将温和升值，具体取决于经济复苏的程度。

;乌克兰无人机和导弹战争的强度已经在欧洲国家中留下了空白专家表示，防空系统的堵塞将很困难、耗时且成本高昂。

;

;防空系统很可能在周一开始的巴黎航空展上扮演主角，管理人员理查德·阿布拉菲亚 (Richard Aboulafia) 预测AeroDynamic Advisory 总监。

;

;“您会看到很多关于导弹生产能力的讨论。导弹市场无疑是该行业中增长最快的部分，但制造商根本跟不上，”阿布拉菲亚说。

;

;自冷战结束以来，西方国家一直享有对天空的完全掌控战争和曾经旨在保护北约部队免受苏联飞机攻击的强大防御系统在很大程度上被放弃了。

;

;国会议员在最近的一份报告中指出，法国摆脱了其九个高射炮团中的八个。

;

;普京说俄罗斯的核弹现在在白俄罗斯，向西方发出警告

;

;但随着越来越多的国家获得巡航导弹、短程弹道导弹，北约国家近年来再次转向防空美国战略与国际研究中心 (CSIS) 高级顾问、退休的美国海军陆战队上校 Mark Cancian 说。

;

;“他们开始了，但基本上没有得到太远了，”Cancian 说。

;

;“再过五年，我认为会有更多，但这对乌克兰现在没有帮助，”他补充说。

;

;由于缺乏防空系统及其发射的导弹，西方正努力响应乌克兰的补给请求——无论是短程防御还是远程防御。

;

;柏林计划斥资 50 亿美元1000 亿欧元（1100 亿美元）的基金用于在未来几年重建其武装部队，用于防空系统，巴黎为 2030 年期间制定了相同的预算。

;

;关于工业方面，欧洲导弹制造商 MBDA 最近几个月与法国和意大利签署了价值 20 亿欧元的合同，供应 700 枚 Aster 导弹，特别用于 SAMP/T 系统。

;

;波兰将花费 22 亿欧元在 44 个发射器和数百枚 CAMM 导弹上。

;

;在德国的带领下，17 个欧洲国家去年通过“欧洲天盾”项目在防空方面联合起来——尽管法国、意大利和波兰都没有参加。

;

;该计划将涉及短程、中程和远程系统的联合采购，包括德国制造的 Iris-T、美国爱国者和美以 Arrow-3。

;

;Aboulafia 说，“在盟国之间进行协调”“意义重大”。

;

;然而，“每当北约试图标准化时，显然必须在谁领导生产和设计”，他补充道。

;

;“我们以前看过这部电影，但最大的问题始终是法国，”阿布拉菲亚说，法国不愿放弃工业领导地位。

;

;乌克兰：俄罗斯导弹在哈尔科夫杀死 4 人，大使呼吁更多支持

;

;和经济水平，”总部位于柏林的智库 SWP 在最近的一份报告中写道。

;

;通过选择美国和以色列的技术而不是欧洲，德国领导的计划也“与目标不一致加强欧洲的工业和技术防御基础”，SWP 补充说。

;

;法国国会议员最近的报告直接批评了天盾，感叹“完全缺乏欧洲的解决方案……与美国和以色列产品的推广”。< /p>;

;在俄罗斯向乌克兰发射其大肆宣传的 Kinzhal 核武后，以色列的另一项产品是 Rafael Defense Systems 的新型高超音速导弹拦截器，下周在巴黎展示时可能会吸引欧洲各国政府。

;

;除了巴黎航展之外，法国政府还邀请部长们参加防空会议，试图平息分歧。

;

;“德国人提出了一项工业协议，我们提出了一项战略倡议：拥有欧洲主权防空能力和欧洲装备，”一位法国外交消息人士说。

;中国最大的珠宝零售商周大福珠宝集团正在进军更小、更少随着全球最大消费市场的零售支出放缓，中国内地富裕城市寻求增长。

;

;低线城市的年轻消费者对黄金和钻石的偏好日益增强，时机成熟常务董事 Kent Wong Siu-kee 说：“我们发现一些顾客会从他们的家乡前往一线城市光顾我们的商店，”他说。在上海的媒体发布会上告诉记者。 “下线城市的消费者愿意[在珠宝上]消费，我们需要在他们力所能及的范围内开设门店。”

;

;Wong 表达了对中国经济的信心，并预测近期的动荡将出现转机

;

;中国大陆目前占周大福总收入的近 90%。这家在香港上市的零售商在内地经营着 7,269 家门店，其中大部分位于富裕的一线和二线城市。

;

;在实现了过去在内地开设 7,000 家门店的目标之后比计划提前两年的财政年度，该公司计划在本财政年度在大陆再增加 600 至 800 家门店。

;

;在消费市场疲软的情况下，这一数字表明扩张速度有所放缓。周大福在上个财政年度新开了 1,600 家门店。

;

;Wong 表示，公司将专注于帮助新门店作为业务发展。一家新珠宝店通常需要大约两年时间才能赢得良好声誉并吸引大量客流量。

;

;“像周大福这样的顶级珠宝零售商拥有庞大的客户群，这对他们来说并不罕见在制定和执行扩张计划时也有更高的风险偏好，”营销和品牌公司上海亚城文化的首席执行官陈晓说。

;

;和珠宝零售商将面临留住忠实客户的困难。”

;

;中国人长期以来一直有投资黄金的传统，认为贵金属是对抗通货膨胀的最佳保值工具。

;

;在 Covid-19 大流行期间，随着消费者购买更多黄金作为避险投资，周大福在中国迅速扩张。

;

;它最初由周志远于 1929 年在广州成立。他的女婿郑裕彤从珠宝店学徒起家，帮助周大福在香港扩张，1956 年接管公司。

;

;即使在经过三年严厉的反新冠疫情措施后重新开放后，零售额仍然低迷。

;

;数据显示，上月零售额同比增长 12.7%，比 4 月份 18.4% 的年度增幅低 5.7 个百分点国家统计局的数据显示。

;

;增长低于预期的同比增长 13.6%，这是基于上海数据提供商 Wind Information 对分析师的调查得出的。

;

;16 至 24 岁人群的失业率在 5 月份创下 20.8% 的新高，高于 4 月份的 20.4%，这加剧了人们对消费者支出进一步下滑的担忧。

;Makeshiki 大步穿过狂欢者时显得格外引人注目。对于一个日本男人来说个子很高——不可否认，他的靴子让他显得更高了——他从头到脚都穿着纯黑色乳胶，尽管遮住他脸的紧身兜帽有眼睛和嘴巴的开口，上面有一圈红色的环。

;

;这种反文化性行为的表达在日本的日常生活中是不可能发生的，但在这里，在东京电影俱乐部 H 部的安全空间内，这个国家的恋物癖者可以将他们的喜好表现在他们的袖子上。假设他们穿了那么多衣服。

;

;“在过去的七年里，我每个月都来这里，”Makeshiki 说，他对泄露太多保持谨慎。他今年 37 岁，在日本一家大型电信公司工作，但不愿提供可能识别他身份的详细信息。

;

;“我是一名工薪族。几年前，我发现我喜欢乳胶，”他说。 “但这是我的秘密。我从来没有告诉过我的家人或朋友，甚至是我最亲密的朋友。我不认为他们会理解。事实上，如果我试图解释，我认为他们不会理解。

;

;“我想我在日本社会经常感到不舒服，我来这里是为了做我自己，”他补充道。

;< p>;“这是我的自由。”

;

;这是我在整个晚上听到的一次又一次表达的情绪。

;

;H 部门今年庆祝成为东京的 15 周年各种恋物癖者的首要活动，尽管它的历史可以追溯到 1994 年在涩谷举行的第一届 Salon KittyFire 2099 晚会。

;

;该活动的名称来源于 X 战警漫画中的加拿大政府部门- 系列丛书，其成员包括 Northstar——美国漫画中最早出现的公开同性恋角色之一。

;

;虽然在冠状病毒大流行期间晚上比较安静，但参加派对的人现在正在弥补失去的时间。

;

;H 部门在每个月的第一个星期六举行，午夜开门，最后一批参加者通常在黎明破晓之后在情趣酒店、酒吧和便利店林立​​的莺谷区迎来。

; p>;

;日本将同意年龄从 13 岁提高到 16 岁，因为前青少年明星寻求改变

;

;每个活动都有一个主题，例如愚人节和一个专门为女性相扑选手举办的晚会。日本婚庆行业热衷于“六月新娘”，所以我在门厅迎接了两个身材魁梧的易装癖者，她们身穿蕾丝婚纱、面纱、高跟鞋和两对大而飘扬的睫毛。

;

;身份证是仔细检查后，在接待处，我很快发现我穿的 T 恤和短裤严重不足。入场费是 5,000 日元（36 美元），不过前台那位戴着假发、穿着黑色丁字裤、穿着渔网连体袜的迷人女士让我知道，如果我接下来在着装上多加努力，我会得到折扣

;

;镶嵌在墙上的一个大玻璃盒子里装着“今日捕获物”，一个有着美人鱼尾巴的赤裸上身的女人端庄地微笑着向路人挥手致意。双开门通向一个优雅弯曲的阳台，里面挤满了身穿链条和皮革、橡胶、乳胶或薄薄薄纱的男男女女，这些衣服的设计让人无法想象任何东西。

;

;在一个角落里，一个男人正在监督关于 shibari 的研讨会，日本的绳索束缚艺术，提供结的技巧和最好的绳索使用方法。在附近，纹身恋物癖者正在比较身体各个部位的皮肤墨水，而其他人则欣赏穿孔。一个戴着防毒面具和一条内裤的男人走过。一个身穿红色皮衣的矮个子女人拉着一个拴着皮带的男人，他急忙爬过去跟上。

;

;Mayumi 在会场一楼的舞台旁边跳舞，头发向后梳，用皮带束起来

;

;“我猜这是出于好奇，”当被问及她今晚为什么来这里时，她说。

;

;“这是我第二次来。我很享受第一次，还遇到了一些有趣的人，所以我想我会再试一次。”

;

;这位 40 岁的顾问说，H 部门“气氛很好，任何人都可以做自己想做的事.我真的很喜欢那种自由。”

;

;突然，舞台上活跃起来，司仪站在聚光灯下，穿着婚纱。掌声震耳欲聋。在晚上的庆祝活动真正开始之前，MC 介绍了他的“新娘”同伴。

;

;Galatia Suzaku 和 Norio Ichigozaki 穿着更传统的日本婚礼服装，为新娘增加了狐狸面具，并表演一个运动部分舞蹈部分脱衣舞，以他们的内衣结束。接下来在舞台上，绞刑专家村上隆巧妙地捆绑了他柔顺的受害者 Jin，并将他抬下了舞台。作为结局，村上将 Jin 水平悬吊起来，并对其进行了几次电击。

;

;不允许同性婚姻是“违宪状态”：日本法院

;

;Tosuke 已尽其所能走到人群前面，热烈鼓掌。

;

;“这个地方对我和像我这样的人来说很特别，”他说。 “在这里，我可以成为任何我想成为的人，做任何我想做的事。 H部门是无障碍的。”

;

;Tosuke是一位54岁的动漫艺术家，他身材矮小，身材魁梧，自称是“同性恋熊”，也喜欢表演滑稽表演。

;< p>;他驳斥了一些人认为 Department H 是东京性少数群体的接机点的观点。

;

;“这不是这一切的目的，”他说。 “有很多酒吧和俱乐部，同性恋者或其他任何人都可以在那里结识其他人。但今晚的一切都是为了玩得开心，做我们想做的事。”

;

;得到 Tosuke 的认可，舞台上的下一幕是一位成功的滑稽舞者，他充分利用了一对鲜红的羽毛扇子.一队桑巴舞者身着耀眼的王权和轻薄的服装，开始跳舞，因为人群开始把事情掌握在自己手中。

;

;一个有着鲜红色头发、皮革绑带和镶钉衣领的女人已经三名自愿的参与者靠墙排成一排，正用九尾猫敲打他们裸露的臀部。

;

;附近，一名穿着皮革和高跟鞋的年轻女子跨坐在一名跪着的中年男子身上并且正在热情地拍打他的臀部，而就在几码远的地方，一个裹着绷带的女孩在舞台上唱歌，我猜这是假血。

;

;在我们周围，没有人眨眼。

;

;当我注视时，优子悄悄靠近我。她穿着高中女生穿的那种一体式泳衣，看起来大约 15 岁——但告诉我她已经 35 岁了。

;

;她靠过去让别人听到她的声音，并重复了一遍-听说日本社会不开放，在这里，在 H 部门，她可以做自己，真正感到“自由”。

;

;她仍然盯着我的眼睛，伸出手，用不可磨灭的记号笔画了一个我前臂上的笑脸。带着少年的笑容和30多岁的洞察力，她加上了赤坎两个字。

;

;意思是色狼，洗不掉。没有人能毫发无损地离开H部门。

;香港人陈嘉敏24岁时被诊断患有自闭症，最后解释了她小时候和在学校面临的障碍，以及她与母亲的冲突。

;

;

; Sun, 18 Jun 2023 12:20:02 +0800 Will ChatGPT and similar generative AI tools worsen China’s job crisis? Country’s employment landscape faces sweeping disruptionhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3224162/will-chatgpt-and-similar-generative-ai-tools-worsen-chinas-job-crisis-countrys-employment-landscape?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.18 11:00;
;;

;In the southwestern tech hub of Chengdu, capital of Sichuan province, Matthew Chen co-founded a small video gaming studio and publisher that has recently embraced generative artificial intelligence (AI) technology to become more efficient, while vastly reducing its manpower requirements – an emerging trend in the world's second-largest economy.

;

;By adopting two foreign-developed tools – Stable Diffusion, a deep-learning system that generates detailed images based on text descriptions, and AI chatbot ChatGPT – which are both officially not available in China, Chen's company has done away this year with an army of contractors who used to do translation work.

;

;“ChatGPT translates much faster, and it costs only US$20 a month,” Chen said. By comparison, a third-party translation firm can charge as much as 100,000 yuan (US$14,000) for a year's contract, he said.

;

;Copywriters, foreign-language customer service employees and some illustrators can also be replaced by AI, according to Chen. He said his company is experimenting with Stable Diffusion, which turns text prompts into images, to make rough sketches into images. This system can be about 80 per cent as good as a human illustrator, he said.

;

;The changes made at Chen's video gaming studio represent a small fraction of the sweeping disruptions brought by generative AI technology to certain traditional occupations in China and the country's broader job market.

;

;In a global analysis published in late March, Goldman Sachs estimated that generative AI could automate as many as 300 million full-time jobs.

;

;The US investment bank found that one-quarter of current tasks could be automated by AI in the US and Europe, listing sectors such as office administrative support, legal, architecture and engineering.

;

;The stakes appear higher in China, where low birth rates have combined with a rapidly ageing population to result in a widening demographic imbalance. This situation has also been complicated by the country's record-high youth unemployment rate.

;

;AI may put half of China's jobs at risk. We asked ChatGPT for career advice

;

;There are 11.6 million new university graduates this summer, some 820,000 more than last year, who will enter China's job market, which is already awash with unsuccessful jobseekers who finished college during the coronavirus pandemic.

;

;A recent study conducted by Zhang Dandan, an associate professor at Peking University's National Development School, on 1.2 million job posts in a Chinese recruitment website found that employment opportunities are quickly disappearing for positions that can be easily replaced by AI, including in sales, accounting, training, software development, office management and client services, according to a report by Shanghai-based digital media outlet Jiemian.

;

;The study suggested that AI is taking away more traditional occupations in China than creating new jobs, which is a trend that may intensify, Zhang was quoted by Jiemian as saying. She shared her research at an academic symposium last month in the nation's capital.

;

;While the Chinese government has yet to provide an estimate of the overall AI-related disruptions in the country's job market, the technology's impact is becoming more pronounced. One of the hardest-hit sectors is overseas study agency, in which intermediaries prepare the relevant paperwork for overseas study applications, according to a recent report by state-controlled National Business Daily, which said ChatGPT was killing this trade.

;

;ChatGPT boss says AI won't spark mass jobs extinction

;

;The report quoted Zhang Ye, who runs a firm that assists Chinese students to study overseas, as saying that his company has already lost more than 60 per cent of its business in “polishing” applications to “high-quality” work done via ChatGPT.

;

;Using a large language model (LLM) like GPT-4, the latest version developed by US start-up OpenAI for its ChatGPT service, also costs less than 1 per cent of hiring a human data analyst while turning in comparable performances, according to a recent study by Damo Academy, the in-house research arm of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding, and Singapore's Nanyang Technological University. Alibaba owns the South China Morning Post.

;

;An LLM is a deep-learning algorithm that can recognise, summarise, translate, predict and generate text and other content based on knowledge gained from massive data sets.

;

;At present, China's government is yet to officially approve any domestic ChatGPT-style services. Baidu's Ernie Bot, SenseTime's SenseChat, iFlytek's SparkDesk and Alibaba's Tongyi Qianwen are all considered in “trial mode”. Both ChatGPT and Google's Bard, meanwhile, are not directly available in China, which has the world's largest internet population.

;

;AI sector a bright spot in tough jobs market for China's graduates

;

;Still, tech-savvy Chinese users have used ChatGPT in various local endeavours.

;

;A social sciences researcher and college professor, surnamed Zhang, described ChatGPT as being “very reliable” in his data analysis for R, a programming language for statistical computing and graphics, and the general-purpose Python programming language.

;

;“I used to spend 20 to 30 per cent of my time on assignments” such as composing course syllabuses, drafting speech scripts for faculty deans and writing meeting agendas, Zhang said. “ChatGPT is pretty good at generating content that doesn't have to contain arguments or originality, but it won't turn out an avant-garde academic paper.”

;

;There are also certain enterprises and industries that have widely adopted these new AI tools and created new job opportunities.

;

;Copywriters, designers, illustrators and translators can also use generative AI to improve their work and not necessarily be replaced, according to Pascale Fung, director of the Centre for Artificial Intelligence Research at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.

;

;“Jobs that are likely to be created are those that use AI to improve their efficiency and creativity,” Fung said. “There will be a new generation of AI designers, content creators, analysts, architects, artists and more who know how to harvest the power of generative AI.”

;

;On Boss Zhipin, a Chinese recruiting platform that targets tech workers, at least 27 vacancies were listed this week for “prompt engineers”, a relatively new role to optimise the interaction with generative AI.

;

;Employers included some of China's biggest internet firms, including TikTok owner ByteDance, voice recognition giant iFlytek and Jidu, an electric car venture backed by Baidu and carmaker Geely. Hangzhou-based intelligent marketing agency Mogic is also looking for about five prompt engineers, which are new positions created in May, according to a company representative in charge of technology in a written response to the Post.

;

;A prompt engineer is expected to have comprehensive capabilities to understand LLMs, write code, analyse data and know marketing. “For example, the prompt engineer has to understand how a short video works to ask generative AI to provide the right scripts,” the Mogic representative said.

;

;Even for China's fresh graduates, those with degrees related to LLMs are in short supply, as the number of job openings surged 172.5 per cent from a year earlier, according to job search platform Liepin's 2023 employment report for Chinese university graduates.

;Hong Kong's plan to import workers will allow airlines to increase the number of flights and help the aviation industry to bring airfares down to a “reasonable level” by the peak season in winter, the city's airport chief has said.

;

;A shortage of local ground crew had left 20 airlines struggling to increase flight numbers over the past three months, Airport Authority CEO Fred Lam Tin-fuk also revealed on Sunday.

;

;“We hope the number of flights and passengers will be restored to 80 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by the end of this year [with the new measure],” he said.

;

;Last week, Hong Kong unveiled plans to import up to 20,000 workers to support the construction, transport and aviation sectors, which would bypass vetting procedures by the Labour Advisory Board.

;

;Will importing 20,000 workers fix Hong Kong's labour woes?

;

;As part of the initiative, the aviation sector is allowed to bring in 6,300 workers.

;

;Lam said the airport's manpower crunch, which included a shortage of ground staff, drivers, aircrew and maintenance workers, had prevented airlines from ramping up their flight capacity and stalled the industry's recovery.

;

;He expected the first batch of imported workers to arrive in October and complete their training by December, just in time for the travel season peak around Christmas.

;

;“Airlines are eager to increase the number of flights to meet the demand over Christmas,” he said. “We hope the imported workers can help us increase the number of flights and bring airfares down to a relatively reasonable level.”

;

;Some travel agents had earlier said airfares in Hong Kong had soared by between 15 and 40 per cent compared with pre-pandemic prices.

;

;Cathay Pacific Airways, the city's flagship carrier, previously predicted airfares would remain high until the end of next year, noting that demand for tickets had exceeded the supply.

;

;The city's flag carrier and its budget arm HK Express in March reached 50 per cent of their pre-pandemic passenger capacity, compared with regional rival Singapore Airlines Group at 79 per cent.

;

;On Sunday, Lam also brushed aside concerns that importing labour would have a negative impact on local workers, arguing they could take on the task of supervising newcomers.

;

;Highlighting the importance of adopting technology and automatisation to minimise the demand for manpower, he pledged to attract young local talent to join the industry through the Hong Kong International Aviation Academy.

;

;Importation of labour is not enough to address wider problem facing Hong Kong

;

;Despite Hong Kong's drive to bring in more labour, the Staffs and Workers Union of Hong Kong Civil Airlines earlier predicted airport operators would struggle to win over workers from nearby mainland Chinese cities with the current compensation packages.

;

;Citing talks with Shenzhen-based airport workers, it argued that mainlanders would prefer similar-paying jobs back home without the hassle of relocating or long daily commutes.

;

;Deputy Financial Secretary Michael Wong Wai-lun had conceded the plan would have to contend with the commuting “challenge” and competition from other cities, but argued the pay in Hong Kong was still higher than across the border.

;;2023.06.18 10:30;
;;

;Three times a week, 20 yuan (US$2.8) at a time, Beijing-based banker Fred Jia has made buying lottery tickets a routine after work.

;

;He picked up the habit because of the football World Cup last year, and went on to buy other types of tickets after the tournament in Qatar had ended.

;

;Each time, the 28-year-old squeezes through the crowd – many of them middle-aged men with cigarettes in hand, reading charts dotted with past winning numbers and sharing experiences – in the small lottery storefront near his home, before raising his voice to ask the shopkeeper to input his lucky numbers.

;

;Most of the time, the money is just poured down the drain, except for the few occasions when he has won as much as 20 yuan to just break even.

;

;“I want to be rich and change my life, but my job can't bring me that,” he said. “How do you know you won't be the next big winner?”

;

;Amid a weak post-coronavirus economic recovery and a worsening job market, more young Chinese like Jia have found solace in buying lottery tickets, pinning their hopes for a better future more on gambling than hard work.

;

;In the past year, lottery shops and vending machines have sprung up in shopping centres and underground train stations, with young people forming long queues to try their luck.

;

;Gambling in China is generally banned apart from the China Sports Lottery and China Welfare Lottery, both of which have traditional lotteries that involve selecting numbers and also scratch cards that offer the potential of instant success.

;

;The sports lottery involves an element of gaming as customers predict the outcome of football matches and levy wagers on the results. The China Welfare Lottery, meanwhile, uses the sale of lottery tickets to help the development of social welfare.

;

;Social media posts have also been flooding various Chinese platforms, with the slogan “winning 10 million is easier than earning 10 million” becoming the new life motto of many.

;

;Wayne Zheng was dragged into buying scratch cards last year by videos on popular Chinese video-sharing service Bilibili.

;

;The 27-year-old watched as others bought cards in bulk, and whenever they won – no matter how much – he felt happy for them.

;

;Zheng then started to buy scratch cards for himself, and whenever he passed a shop, he would spend 50 yuan to 200 yuan. If he won at a specific shop, he would make sure he returned.

;

;“It was during the Covid-19 pandemic, when I felt life was very difficult and stressful,” the Shanghai resident said.

;

;“I started to buy [scratch cards] because I really want to get rich overnight.”

;

;According to the Ministry of Finance, a record 175.15 billion yuan (US$24.5 billion) worth of lottery tickets and scratch cards were sold nationwide in the first four months of the year – increasing by 49.3 per cent compared to the same period last year.

;

;All of China's 31 provincial-level jurisdictions recorded a surge in sales during the same period, the data showed.

;

;The ministry attributed the surge in sales to popular sports events like the football World Cup, as well as the promotion of new lottery games – mainly scratch cards.

;

;But bleaker economic prospects, together with the government's worsening financial situation, are deeper reasons, economists said.

;

;Dan Wang, chief economist at Hang Seng Bank China, said Beijing does not normally encourage buying lottery tickets and scratch cards because it is by nature a form of gambling, but such elevated revenues reflect difficulties in raising funds through more conventional means.

;

;In 2021, out of the 373.3 billion yuan worth of lottery tickets and scratch cards sold nationwide, 28 per cent – or 104.7 billion yuan – ended up as government revenue, which was further split evenly between central and local governments and designated for public welfare spending, according to the Ministry of Finance.

;

;Last week, the ministry approved 20 new types of sports-themed scratch cards.

;

;“Lottery is essentially a tax on the poor,” Wang said.

;

;“The job market is particularly harsh on low-income groups during economic downturns. Many turn to lotteries as an escape.”

;

;The trend seems particularly strong for young people, as they are under the highest pressure to find a job this year, she added.

;

;In May, China's unemployment rate among the 16-24 age group hit a record high of 20.8 per cent, rising from 20.4 per cent in April.
